lines.text: Enter OCTAVIUS, ANTONY, and their army

lines.speaker: octavius
lines.text: Now, Antony, our hopes are answered: You said the enemy would not come down, But keep the hills and upper regions; It proves not so: their battles are at hand; They mean to warn us at Philippi here, Answering before we do demand of them.

lines.speaker: antony
lines.text: Tut, I am in their bosoms, and I know Wherefore they do it: they could be content To visit other places; and come down With fearful bravery, thinking by this face To fasten in our thoughts that they have courage; But 'tis not so.
Enter a Messenger

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: Prepare you, generals: The enemy comes on in gallant show; Their bloody sign of battle is hung out, And something to be done immediately.

lines.speaker: antony
lines.text: Octavius, lead your battle softly on, Upon the left hand of the even field.

lines.speaker: octavius
lines.text: Upon the right hand I; keep thou the left.

lines.speaker: antony
lines.text: Why do you cross me in this exigent?

lines.speaker: octavius
lines.text: I do not cross you; but I will do so.
March
Drum. Enter BRUTUS, CASSIUS, and their Army; LUCILIUS, TITINIUS, MESSALA, and others

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: They stand, and would have parley.

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: Stand fast, Titinius: we must out and talk.

lines.speaker: octavius
lines.text: Mark Antony, shall we give sign of battle?

lines.speaker: antony
lines.text: No, Caesar, we will answer on their charge. Make forth; the generals would have some words.

lines.speaker: octavius
lines.text: Stir not until the signal.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Words before blows: is it so, countrymen?

lines.speaker: octavius
lines.text: Not that we love words better, as you do.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Good words are better than bad strokes, Octavius.

lines.speaker: antony
lines.text: In your bad strokes, Brutus, you give good words: Witness the hole you made in Caesar's heart, Crying 'Long live! hail, Caesar!'

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: Antony, The posture of your blows are yet unknown; But for your words, they rob the Hybla bees, And leave them honeyless.

lines.speaker: antony
lines.text: Not stingless too.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: O, yes, and soundless too; For you have stol'n their buzzing, Antony, And very wisely threat before you sting.

lines.speaker: antony
lines.text: Villains, you did not so, when your vile daggers Hack'd one another in the sides of Caesar: You show'd your teeth like apes, and fawn'd like hounds, And bow'd like bondmen, kissing Caesar's feet; Whilst damned Casca, like a cur, behind Struck Caesar on the neck. O you flatterers!

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: Flatterers! Now, Brutus, thank yourself: This tongue had not offended so to-day, If Cassius might have ruled.

lines.speaker: octavius
lines.text: Come, come, the cause: if arguing make us sweat, The proof of it will turn to redder drops. Look; I draw a sword against conspirators; When think you that the sword goes up again? Never, till Caesar's three and thirty wounds Be well avenged; or till another Caesar Have added slaughter to the sword of traitors.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Caesar, thou canst not die by traitors' hands, Unless thou bring'st them with thee.

lines.speaker: octavius
lines.text: So I hope; I was not born to die on Brutus' sword.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: O, if thou wert the noblest of thy strain, Young man, thou couldst not die more honourable.

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: A peevish schoolboy, worthless of such honour, Join'd with a masker and a reveller!

lines.speaker: antony
lines.text: Old Cassius still!

lines.speaker: octavius
lines.text: Come, Antony, away! Defiance, traitors, hurl we in your teeth: If you dare fight to-day, come to the field; If not, when you have stomachs.
Exeunt OCTAVIUS, ANTONY, and their army

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: Why, now, blow wind, swell billow and swim bark! The storm is up, and all is on the hazard.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Ho, Lucilius! hark, a word with you.

lines.speaker: lucilius
lines.text: [Standing forth] My lord?
BRUTUS and LUCILIUS converse apart

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: Messala!

lines.speaker: messala
lines.text: [Standing forth]  What says my general?

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: Messala, This is my birth-day; as this very day Was Cassius born. Give me thy hand, Messala: Be thou my witness that against my will, As Pompey was, am I compell'd to set Upon one battle all our liberties. You know that I held Epicurus strong And his opinion: now I change my mind, And partly credit things that do presage. Coming from Sardis, on our former ensign Two mighty eagles fell, and there they perch'd, Gorging and feeding from our soldiers' hands; Who to Philippi here consorted us: This morning are they fled away and gone; And in their steads do ravens, crows and kites, Fly o'er our heads and downward look on us, As we were sickly prey: their shadows seem A canopy most fatal, under which Our army lies, ready to give up the ghost.

lines.speaker: messala
lines.text: Believe not so.

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: I but believe it partly; For I am fresh of spirit and resolved To meet all perils very constantly.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Even so, Lucilius.

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: Now, most noble Brutus, The gods to-day stand friendly, that we may, Lovers in peace, lead on our days to age! But since the affairs of men rest still incertain, Let's reason with the worst that may befall. If we do lose this battle, then is this The very last time we shall speak together: What are you then determined to do?

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Even by the rule of that philosophy By which I did blame Cato for the death Which he did give himself, I know not how, But I do find it cowardly and vile, For fear of what might fall, so to prevent The time of life: arming myself with patience To stay the providence of some high powers That govern us below.

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: Then, if we lose this battle, You are contented to be led in triumph Thorough the streets of Rome?

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: No, Cassius, no: think not, thou noble Roman, That ever Brutus will go bound to Rome; He bears too great a mind. But this same day Must end that work the ides of March begun; And whether we shall meet again I know not. Therefore our everlasting farewell take: For ever, and for ever, farewell, Cassius! If we do meet again, why, we shall smile; If not, why then, this parting was well made.

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: For ever, and for ever, farewell, Brutus! If we do meet again, we'll smile indeed; If not, 'tis true this parting was well made.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Why, then, lead on. O, that a man might know The end of this day's business ere it come! But it sufficeth that the day will end, And then the end is known. Come, ho! away! Ride, ride, Messala, ride, and give these bills Unto the legions on the other side. Let them set on at once; for I perceive But cold demeanor in Octavius' wing, And sudden push gives them the overthrow. Ride, ride, Messala: let them all come down.
Exeunt
